techniques.name: Box Breathing
steps: Find a comfortable position
Breathe in slowly for 4 counts
Hold your breath for 4 counts
Breathe out slowly for 4 counts
Hold empty for 4 counts
Repeat 4-6 times
techniques.whyItWorks: Activates the parasympathetic nervous system, reducing the fight-or-flight response and lowering cortisol levels.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Crisis Toolkit - Breathing Exercises

techniques.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
steps: Name 5 things you can SEE around you
Name 4 things you can TOUCH or feel
Name 3 things you can HEAR
Name 2 things you can SMELL
Name 1 thing you can TASTE
techniques.whyItWorks: Anchors you to the present moment by engaging all five senses, breaking the cycle of anxious or intrusive thoughts.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Crisis Toolkit - Grounding Techniques

techniques.name: Ice Cube Technique
steps: Get an ice cube from the freezer
Hold it in your hand or against your wrist
Focus on the intense cold sensation
Notice as your mind shifts to the physical feeling
Hold until craving passes or ice melts
techniques.whyItWorks: The intense physical sensation redirects the brain from craving or urge to the present-moment experience.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Crisis Toolkit - Physical Techniques

techniques.name: Thought Defusion
steps: Notice the negative thought
Say 'I notice I'm having the thought that...'
Imagine the thought as words on a screen
Watch the words scroll by without grabbing them
Return attention to present moment
techniques.whyItWorks: Creates distance between you and your thoughts, reducing their emotional impact and power over your actions.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - CBT Skills - Cognitive Techniques

techniques.name: Urge Surfing
steps: Notice the urge without acting on it
Imagine the urge as a wave in the ocean
Observe as the wave builds in intensity
Remind yourself: waves always crest and fall
Ride the wave without letting it knock you over
Notice as the intensity naturally decreases
techniques.whyItWorks: Urges naturally peak and subside within 15-30 minutes. By observing rather than fighting, you build tolerance and confidence.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Distress Tolerance

techniques.name: Opposite Action
steps: Identify the emotion you're feeling
Notice what the emotion is urging you to do
Ask: Is acting on this urge effective right now?
If not, do the OPPOSITE of what the urge suggests
For sadness: move, connect, get active
For anxiety: approach instead of avoid
For anger: be gentle, step back
techniques.whyItWorks: Emotions come with action urges. By doing the opposite, you can change the emotion itself.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Emotion Regulation

techniques.name: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
steps: Find a comfortable position
Start with your feet - tense muscles for 5 seconds
Release and notice the relaxation for 10 seconds
Move to calves, thighs, abdomen, chest
Continue to hands, arms, shoulders, face
End with a full-body scan feeling relaxation
techniques.whyItWorks: Systematic tension and release trains your body to recognize and release stress, activating the relaxation response.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Crisis Toolkit - Relaxation

techniques.name: Half-Smile Technique
steps: Relax your face completely
Lift the corners of your mouth just slightly
Not a full smile - just the hint of one
Keep your eyes soft and relaxed
Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute
Notice any shift in how you feel
techniques.whyItWorks: Facial expressions can influence emotions (facial feedback hypothesis). A slight smile can shift internal state.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Distress Tolerance

techniques.name: Radical Acceptance
steps: Notice you're fighting against reality
Say: 'This is happening. It is what it is.'
Acceptance doesn't mean approval
Fighting reality only adds suffering
Ask: 'What can I control right now?'
Focus energy on controllable actions
techniques.whyItWorks: Pain is inevitable; suffering from fighting reality is optional. Acceptance frees energy for effective action.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Distress Tolerance

techniques.name: Check the Facts
steps: What emotion am I feeling?
What event triggered this emotion?
What are my interpretations/assumptions?
Are these facts or interpretations?
What's the evidence for and against?
Is there another way to see this?
Does my emotional intensity fit the facts?
techniques.whyItWorks: Emotions respond to our interpretations, not just events. Checking facts can reduce intensity when interpretations are inaccurate.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - CBT Skills - Cognitive Techniques

techniques.name: Self-Soothing Kit
steps: Create a kit with items for each sense:
SIGHT: Photos of loved ones, nature images
SOUND: Calming playlist, nature sounds
SMELL: Essential oils, scented lotion, coffee
TASTE: Mints, herbal tea, favorite healthy snack
TOUCH: Soft blanket, stress ball, smooth stone
Use one or more items when distressed
techniques.whyItWorks: Engaging the senses in pleasurable ways activates the parasympathetic system and provides healthy distraction.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Distress Tolerance

techniques.name: Finding Wise Mind
steps: Notice if you're in Emotional Mind (feelings drive action)
Notice if you're in Reasonable Mind (logic only)
Wise Mind is the overlap of both
Ask: 'What does my Wise Mind know?'
Breathe and listen for the quiet inner voice
Trust the answer that honors both heart and head
techniques.whyItWorks: Neither pure emotion nor pure logic leads to effective decisions. Wise Mind integrates both for balanced action.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Mindfulness

techniques.name: TIPP Skills
steps: T - Temperature: Ice on face, cold water splash
I - Intense exercise: 10-15 minutes high intensity
P - Paced breathing: Slow exhales longer than inhales
P - Paired muscle relaxation: Tense-release with breathing
techniques.whyItWorks: These techniques rapidly activate the parasympathetic nervous system, physically changing your body's crisis state.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Distress Tolerance

techniques.name: STOP Skill
steps: S - STOP: Freeze, don't react
T - TAKE A STEP BACK: Breathe, don't act
O - OBSERVE: What's happening inside and out?
P - PROCEED MINDFULLY: What's the wise action?
techniques.whyItWorks: Creates a pause between stimulus and response, allowing your prefrontal cortex to engage rather than just reacting.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Distress Tolerance

techniques.name: DEAR MAN
steps: D - DESCRIBE the situation factually
E - EXPRESS your feelings using 'I' statements
A - ASSERT what you want clearly
R - REINFORCE why it matters (positive outcome)
M - stay MINDFUL of your goal
A - APPEAR confident (even if nervous)
N - NEGOTIATE if needed
techniques.whyItWorks: Provides a structured approach to difficult conversations that maximizes likelihood of being heard and getting needs met.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - DBT Skills - Interpersonal Effectiveness

techniques.name: 3 Good Things
steps: At the end of each day, write down 3 good things
They can be small (good coffee) or big (job offer)
For each one, answer: Why did this happen?
Focus on your role in making it happen
Notice how it felt in the moment
techniques.whyItWorks: Trains the brain to scan for positives rather than threats, building neural pathways for optimism over time.
techniques.appLocation: Tasks tab - Evening Reflection

techniques.name: Body Scan Meditation
steps: Lie down or sit comfortably
Close your eyes and take 3 deep breaths
Bring attention to your feet - notice sensations
Slowly move attention up through each body part
Notice without judging: tension, warmth, tingling
If mind wanders, gently return to body
End with awareness of whole body
techniques.whyItWorks: Increases body awareness, promotes relaxation, and helps identify where you hold stress so you can release it.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Crisis Toolkit - Meditation

techniques.name: Play the Tape Forward
steps: You're thinking about using - play it forward
What happens in the first hour? (the 'good' part)
What happens later that night?
What about tomorrow morning?
How do you feel about yourself?
What about your recovery progress?
Who would be affected?
Is it worth it?
techniques.whyItWorks: Cravings focus on the immediate relief. Playing the tape forward reveals the full consequences, weakening the urge.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Recovery Skills - Craving Management

techniques.name: Catch It, Check It, Change It
steps: CATCH IT: What thought just went through my mind?
CHECK IT: Is this thought helpful? Is it accurate?
What cognitive distortion might this be?
CHANGE IT: What's a more balanced thought?
What would I tell a friend thinking this?
techniques.whyItWorks: Cognitive restructuring rewires automatic negative thoughts into more balanced, helpful patterns over time.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - CBT Skills - Cognitive Techniques

techniques.name: Values Compass
steps: List your top 5-7 values (family, health, integrity, etc.)
Rate how aligned your current life is with each (1-10)
Identify the biggest gaps
For each gap, ask: What's one small step toward this value?
Commit to one values-aligned action this week
techniques.whyItWorks: Recovery is easier when it's toward something (values) not just away from something (substances).
techniques.appLocation: Tasks tab - Golden Thread - Goals

techniques.name: Mood-Action Link
steps: Notice: Mood drives behavior drives mood
Waiting to 'feel like' doing something keeps you stuck
Schedule ONE small pleasurable activity
Do it whether you feel like it or not
Notice any mood shift after completing it
Repeat: Actions can create feelings
techniques.whyItWorks: Depression tells us to withdraw, which worsens depression. Action - even without motivation - can break the cycle.
techniques.appLocation: Tasks tab - Habit Tracker

techniques.name: Name It to Tame It
steps: Pause and ask: What am I actually feeling?
Try to name the specific emotion (not just 'bad')
Use an emotion wheel if helpful
Say: 'I'm feeling [emotion] right now'
Notice if naming it reduces intensity
Ask: What might this emotion be telling me?
techniques.whyItWorks: Research shows that labeling emotions activates the prefrontal cortex and calms the amygdala.
techniques.appLocation: Tasks tab - Morning Check-in

techniques.name: Mindful Walking
steps: Walk slowly, slightly slower than normal
Feel your feet contact the ground
Notice the sensation of each step
Feel the air on your skin
When mind wanders, return to feet
No destination needed - just walk
techniques.whyItWorks: Combines the benefits of exercise with mindfulness, grounding the body while calming the mind.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Crisis Toolkit - Movement

techniques.name: Safe Place Visualization
steps: Close your eyes and take deep breaths
Imagine a place where you feel completely safe
It can be real or imaginary
See the details: colors, shapes, light
Hear the sounds: nature, silence, music
Feel the sensations: temperature, textures
Stay here as long as needed
techniques.whyItWorks: The brain responds to vivid imagery similarly to real experience. A mental safe place can create real calm.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Crisis Toolkit - Visualization

techniques.name: Connection Call
steps: Recognize you're struggling alone
Pick up the phone - don't text
Call your sponsor, support person, or meeting line
You don't need to have something to say
Just say: 'I'm struggling and needed to hear a voice'
Let them talk if you can't
techniques.whyItWorks: Isolation is fuel for relapse. Human connection activates calming neural pathways and reminds you you're not alone.
techniques.appLocation: Connect tab - Message Coach

techniques.name: Healthy Distraction
steps: Recognize you need to shift focus
Choose an absorbing activity:
- Physical: exercise, cleaning, walking
- Creative: drawing, music, writing
- Social: call friend, go to meeting
- Mental: puzzle, game, learning
Engage fully until craving passes
techniques.whyItWorks: Cravings are time-limited. Absorbing activities occupy the mind while the craving naturally peaks and fades.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - Recovery Skills - Craving Management

techniques.name: ABC PLEASE
steps: A - Accumulate positives (daily pleasant activities)
B - Build mastery (do one thing that builds competence)
C - Cope ahead (plan for difficult situations)
PL - treat Physical iLlness promptly
E - balance Eating (regular, healthy meals)
A - Avoid mood-altering substances
S - balance Sleep (7-9 hours)
E - get Exercise daily
techniques.whyItWorks: Emotional vulnerability increases when basic needs are unmet. This checklist reduces baseline vulnerability.
techniques.appLocation: Tasks tab - Habit Tracker

techniques.name: Morning Intention
steps: Before getting out of bed or during morning routine
Take 3 deep breaths
Ask: What is my intention for today?
Choose ONE word or phrase (patience, presence, courage)
Visualize yourself embodying this intention
Return to this word throughout the day
techniques.whyItWorks: Setting intention activates the prefrontal cortex and primes the brain to notice opportunities aligned with your goal.
techniques.appLocation: Tasks tab - Morning Check-in

techniques.name: H.A.L.T. Check
steps: When you feel off, ask:
H - Am I HUNGRY? (eat something)
A - Am I ANGRY? (what about?)
L - Am I LONELY? (reach out)
T - Am I TIRED? (rest)
Address the basic need first
Then reassess the problem
techniques.whyItWorks: Basic unmet needs magnify all other problems. Often, addressing HALT eliminates the 'crisis' entirely.
techniques.appLocation: Tasks tab - Morning Check-in

techniques.name: Leaves on a Stream
steps: Close your eyes and imagine a stream
Leaves are floating gently downstream
As thoughts arise, place each on a leaf
Watch the leaf float away downstream
Don't push thoughts - just place and watch
If you get hooked, notice that, and return to stream
Continue for 5-10 minutes
techniques.whyItWorks: Creates distance from thoughts without fighting them. Thoughts lose power when observed rather than engaged.
techniques.appLocation: Guides tab - ACT Skills - Defusion
